378501: Nessian Wilds Ravager.author: ToidiDiPuts
378501: Nessian Wilds Ravager.text_parsed:
This is the only tribute card I've seen that passes the vanilla test. That's all I see the tribute creatures as, vanilla creatures that either:
A: do something relatively useless when they enter the battlefield
B: gain a number of +1/+1 counters that brings them up to a point where they would pass the vanilla test
So when your opponent plays a tribute creature you have a choice: let them do something inconsequential to you and give them an underpowered creature, or give them a creature that has no special effect. (or in the case of Siren of the Fanged Coast you can do both, as the +1/+1 counters do not bring it up to a fair size for the price, but the tribute effect is a permanent mind control.)

...This one's different. It's a fair vanilla creature even without the counters, and the effect is actually relevant. I think this is the only good tribute creature they printed.

378502: Noble Quarry.author: Steaditup
378502: Noble Quarry.text_parsed:
This card did wonders for me at the prerelease. In one game, my opponent had a bunch of 9/9 krakens from Kiora's ultimate in addition to a bunch of giant creatures. My 13/13 Nessian Wilds Ravager was able to just waltz by and hit him for the win. Lures are sick.

The bestow is costly, but think of it this way. You pay 6 mana and a card for 2 lures, or 3 mana and a card for 1 lure. Sounds like a pretty good deal.

3.5/5

378502: Noble Quarry.author: Petertracy
378502: Noble Quarry.text_parsed:
Best Lure effect to date IMO, the enchant option with added value really gets there for me, not to mention the 1/1 for 3 with an effect being a better deal than any 2/2 for 4 with the same effect.

Necrobite and this guy in the same set make Golgari so much more enticing to open than in Theros alone.
Seriously though, fantastic wincon in limited. This guy is such a limited bomb, he gives everything you have unblockable for a turn (IN GREEN). May you open Noble Quarry in all your sealed pools and drafts!

(what's wrong with his leg?)

Sparklewolf is quite good in limited. Easily the second-best of the Nyxborn cycle, close behind Nyxborn Triton.

Combining this with any of the Heroic green commons in Theros is big game in a draft. Staunch-Hearted Warrior turn 4, bestow this turn 5, and you've got an attacking 7/5 that leaves behind a 3/1 on death. That can shut the door on a game very quickly! Deserves a solid 3/5.

378508: Satyr Wayfinder.author: master_biomancer
378508: Satyr Wayfinder.text_parsed:
The best and most obvious comparison to this card is Mulch.

Mulch is a sorcery and can net you more lands however the satyr is a creature which is generally better if you are running self mill because it powers up your splinterfright and what not, and it can be reanimated.

If any thing from Innistrad is still played in your play group I would strongly suggest you recognize the danger this can present.

378508: Satyr Wayfinder.author: Eternal_Blue
378508: Satyr Wayfinder.text_parsed: I would not pay more than G for this. I think people are constantly overestimating the value of a 1/1 that becomes vanilla. I mean, so you got a land out of the deal. Green doesn't really need more lands, does it? And it thinned your deck out--but deck-thinning is pretty much a statistical myth as well. So we're looking at a really awful chumpblocker and a single, worthless land.

378508: Satyr Wayfinder.author: Mode
378508: Satyr Wayfinder.text_parsed:
"(...) Also, sure looks like a Scout to me. What gives?" — HuntingDrake

I tend to agree, and I'd have liked him as a Satyr Scout.
But despite the name and suggestive image, when you look at it flavorwise (by reading the flavortext and remembering what Satyrs are all about), you'll notice the only thing Satyrs are scouting for are parties and new ways to get wasted, so Wizards probably didn't make him a Scout for a reason :P


He would be so incredibly good if he could give you multiple lands like Mulch as well (or if he had 2 power).

But I think he'll still do a decent job in the right deck — he'll usually get you a land and mills you for three.
(Or just mills you for four, which will happen either by bad chance or because you really want to — thanks to the may-clause — since you can profit from that, e.g. by getting Threshold)

378508: Satyr Wayfinder.author: HotHit
378508: Satyr Wayfinder.text_parsed:
The unsung backbone of my standard Golgari Reanimator deck. Being a creature helps the deck actually work and lands are easily what I want to find, unlike commune with the Gods which can only grab creatures and enchantments, which it is preventing me from playing.

Whip of Erebos, Pharika's Mender, Grisly Salvage, Elvish Mystic, Rescue from the underworld, Forsaken Drifters, Returned Centaur, Deadbridge Chant and, of course, Ashen Rider (and the Lotleth Troll to discard it). Reanimator's looking pretty strong right now and I'm willing to bet that if you pull Pharika in draft you'll be able to force a sweet reanimator deck.

If nothing else it's a powerful deck for kitchen tables, which is what I've been enjoying.

378508: Satyr Wayfinder.author: shockmoney
378508: Satyr Wayfinder.text_parsed:
would anyone consider this close to a greenified Augur of Bolas? augur brings a better body in blue, but only searches three deep for instants or sorceries. i love a good spell heavy deck, but it kinda restricts how often i can use augur.

Satyr Wayfinder meanwhile digs (pun intended) four deep for lands, not just basic, and helps ensure future land hits, even if your mana is solid. sure, a 1/1 is more underwelling than a Birds of Paradise in my opinion, but its something to bounce/flick with guys like Nulltread Gargantuan or Restoration Angel.

personally, i found the use for Satyr Wayfinder in a G/W Sun Titan build. using birds and Knight of the Reliquary to ramp, Wayfinder's graveyard toss effect is actually helpful with pumping the knight's P/T and stocking the bin with Titan targets. pretty cool little fella.

378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.author: pyromosh
378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.text_parsed:
This is an awful card.

First, let's assume no ramping and I just play this turn 3.

Turn 1: Forest, other stuff (Experiment One, maybe)
Turn 2: Plains, Yoked Ox.
Turn 3: Forest, This.
Turn 4: Instead of attacking, tap this to eat Yoked Ox. Now I have a tapped 6/6.
Turn 5: Now I have a 6/6 that I can swing with. That I played two turns ago and gave my opponent every opportunity to Doom Blade / Mizzium Mortars, or even Magma Jet or Shock. Oh, and if it gets that big and then gets Doom Bladed, it ate another of my cards in the process. Great.

Let's have a slightly more rosy scenario. It *is* green, after all. Ramping is what it does:

Turn 1: Forest, Elvish Mystic.
Turn 2: Forest, This
Turn 3: Land, Experiment One, Guardians of Meletis. End of Opponent's turn, sac the Guardian to this.
Turn 4: Something else to evolve Experiment One again. Now you finally have an 8/8 trampler to swing with.

That's basically the best-case scenario you can hope for with this card. That's a lot of pieces falling just into the right place to make it work.

The P/T this thing potentially gets to isn't bad. That's not the issue. But it eats cards to get there and does so really slowly. That the only way it will live to see those numbers is if your opponent's deck isn't working correctly. If they can't deal with a 2/2 sitting around for two turns, they deserve to lose.

*Maybe* someone will figure out a way to abuse tokens with this. But that won't make it work *faster*.

I run a deck that has Kalonian Hydra as one of the finishers. Even that's iffy a lot of the times, because the thing sits there as a big, dumb 4/4, begging to be Doom Bladed for a turn, or direct damaged for 4, until I can swing with it. This sits around uselessly for twice as long, and is a 2/2 while it's sitting.

This thing has the same giant "Doom Blade me" sign painted on him, but sits there for *two* turns before it becomes useful in any way, then eats another creature on your side in the process.

You can give this haste, but then it's just as fast as a non-haste creature, because it's tapped for a turn. And you still lose a creature.

This card is a lot like Triad of Fates to me. I absolutely love what they're trying to do with it. But mechanically, it's just too slow in getting there to be useful.
Maybe it would be fun to steal an opponent's Desecration Demon with Portent of Betrayal or similar, then sac it to this. But I don't think combos like that are enough to really make this care *consistantly* useful.

378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.author: Grakling
378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.text_parsed:
@ pyromosh
While I agree that the tap cost is less than desirable, you're thinking about this guy in the wrong way.

Don't sac on your turn, sac at the end of your opponent's turn so you're not leaving yourself open.

Yes he has a big "Shock me" sign on him, but he's only 3 mana. Next turn you can play Kiora and they've already used up their shock on your hydra.

Late game, he's an excellent shield for your fatties. Either they waste a Doom Blade on this guy, they try to kill your fatty and you just sac it in response, or they use two kill-spells. This means you get to keep your P/T on the field, or they have to use double the kill-spells. I think that's excellent efficiency for 3cmc splashable.

Yes he may be somewhat slow, but there are loads of standard and even in-block cards that help get the ball rolling on him. Yes Kalonian Hydra is faster when it hits the table, but Kalonian Hydra is Mythic, and costs 2 more. Strictly harder to come by, and ends up taking at least as many turns to be a threat.

Don't get me wrong, I don't think this guy will be single-handedly winning tournaments for anyone, but he's nothing to scoff at when you pull him out of a pack.

378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.author: JimmyNoobPlayer
378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.text_parsed:
@pyromosh: Scourge of Skola Vale is a way to discourage removal and turn toughness into attacking power, not a straight aggro creature. (And the best-case scenario probably involves Corpsejack Menace.)

As Grakling mentioned, always wait until your opponent's end step or respond to removal. He could work in a Phenax mill deck as a backup plan.

@Achvile: Yes, another fun thing to do with Phyrexian Dreadnought! When it enters the battlefield, choose to sacrifice the Dreadnought (this is not a cost, so it will happen when the ability resolves), and in response sacrifice it to the Scourge.

378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.author: Nucleon
378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.text_parsed:
Huh, interesting. Copying my comment over from M12's Primordial Hydra, I said this back in the day:

"Have to wonder where they'll go from here if they continue this Hydra trend.

Hypothetical Hydra
CMC: XG
P/T: 0/0
Hypothetical Hydra enters the battlefield with X +1/+1 counters on it.
1, Remove a +1/+1 counter from Hypothetical Hydra: Put a 1/1 green Head creature token onto the battlefield.
Sacrifice a creature: Put X +1/+1 counters on Hypothetical Hydra."

I was off on the idea of X-ponential growth, though it seems the "Hydra eats something to grow" idea wound up coming true. I'm sure it's just coincidence, but it's nice to see little moments of "Ooh, I think like the devs do!" sometimes.

378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.author: mattbl
378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.text_parsed:
@pyromosh Judging a card based on its propensity to get removed is a bad way to judge a card. There are some great uses for this card, but trying to get it out and sac a high toughness creature to it ASAP isn't one of them. This works well in a Golgari deck or in a Simic deck that's boosting creatures with counters and cards that can untap like Kiora's Follower. Just because it doesn't fit an aggro/ramp deck doesn't make it awful.

I feel like that's the downfall with the way people think about Magic today. This card doesn't win on turn 3 and it takes more than 1 turn to become an absolute power house, awful card!

With all that said, I was disappointed that this has to tap to sac a creature, but I also understand the need. It would be nicer if you could pay 1G and sac a creature so you could still attack the turn you sac.

Also: Death's Presence, Vastwood Hydra, Worldspine Wurm

378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.author: Crosserenti
378509: Scourge of Skola Vale.text_parsed:
Long story short, this thing can get nasty. With the high amount of hexproof giving cards now, I run this in a Rubinia EDH. I steal your creature, kill it, and smash you with it's toughness. Protecting it is easy enough, as white, blue, and green all have ways to keep things alive, like Fanatical Devotion, which is just as strong in it. Add other steal cards, like beguiler. Hope they are playing black, red, or blue control. Oh wait, birthing pod and Teferi...talk about hopeless...

Still, outside of that, it is a tad slow. Protecting it would have to be a priority, which can slow you down...

a solid 3/5, imo

378511: Setessan Starbreaker.author: Ferlord
378511: Setessan Starbreaker.text_parsed:
While I'm hearing lots of love for this card in draft, no one mentions Priest of Iroas.

When you need a chump blocker, it's a 1/1 for . When you need to destroy an Enchantment (not just an Aura), it's . If you play the creature first and then wait, the destruction happens at instant speed. It's more colourful, but what it really does is create a threat.

Your opponents will be less likely to play big enchantments unless they're willing to reciprocate. That means that you could save yourself a few turns before they play those.

I honestly hate this card because it's still a "kill spell", but it's so inefficient that I'd rather just draft a creature like Pheres-Band Tromper and let them deal with me rather than the other way around.

Your opponents will be less likely to play big enchantments unless they're willing to reciprocate. That means that you could save yourself a few turns before they play those. 

I honestly hate this card because it's still a "kill spell", but it's so inefficient that I'd rather just draft a creature like Pheres-Band Tromper and let them deal with me rather than the other way around.

378511: Setessan Starbreaker.author: Bbone37
378511: Setessan Starbreaker.text_parsed:
For everyone comparing this to War Priest of Thune, do you even play limited? How rare/what CMC would you expect to have a creature at that can kill a vast majority of the set? If this guy said "ETB: Kill 1/2 the cards in the block", what do you think his rarity would be? What would you want to pay? Do you think a 2CMC bear that had such power could be at common or even uncommon? Would you even play anything BUT that bear?

I'm not saying I like this dude. Like others said it is only aruas, not enchantments, so it MAY not hit. BUT, if it were like War Preist, costed only 2 mana, and killed ANY enchantment, then it would be WAY overpowered for limited. Its like if a 2 drop shatter-bear was a common in Mirrodin blocks... wouldn't happen. It would break the format, and limited wouldn't be fun.

So yeah, for constructed, if you have access to obv run the priest. But not every card is designed with constructed in mind. There are many formats in which one can play MTG, and not all of them have access to the entire library. Please keep this in mind when making such narrowminded general statements.
378511: Setessan Starbreaker.text_posted:
For everyone comparing this to War Priest of Thune, do you even play limited? How rare/what CMC would you expect to have a creature at that can kill a vast majority of the set? If this guy said "ETB: Kill 1/2 the cards in the block", what do you think his rarity would be? What would you want to pay? Do you think a 2CMC bear that had such power could be at common or even uncommon? Would you even play anything BUT that bear?

I'm not saying I like this dude. Like others said it is only aruas, not enchantments, so it MAY not hit. BUT, if it were like War Preist, costed only 2 mana, and killed ANY enchantment, then it would be WAY overpowered for limited. Its like if a 2 drop shatter-bear was a common in Mirrodin blocks... wouldn't happen. It would break the format, and limited wouldn't be fun. 

So yeah, for constructed, if you have access to [W] obv run the priest. But not every card is designed with constructed in mind. There are many formats in which one can play MTG, and not all of them have access to the entire library. Please keep this in mind when making such narrowminded general statements.

378515: Unravel the Aether.author: Dragon_Punch
378515: Unravel the Aether.text_parsed:
@Curlie-Joe Because if it were worded as you suggest, you would be the one shuffling it into your opponents library. Which is never how that type of effect goes. It's always the opponent shuffling their thing into their library or you shuffling your thing into yours.

It's like how you always bounce something into its owners hand. I would assume this is because wizards doesn't want to encourage people holding/concealing other people's (possibly strangers) cards/libraries for the purpose of cheating or stealing. This second paragraph is basically just speculation, but I stand by it.

Card is 5/5 for me.

Flying + Trample makes it ultra hard to successfully block this guy.

First Strike makes him immune to things like Vampire Nighthawk, but the large amount of auras in this block will make it easier to get around the first strike.

Vigilance lets you kill more creatures with him, or it can let you use things like Power of Fire with him and attack.

Lifelink gets you 8+ life a round with this guy, which should be enough to stabilize your life total.

All around, a very powerful card if you can play him. Channel the Suns helps a lot (Like Shadowcaster3975 said). The temples should also help, as they both fix mana and help you search fro the right land.

378516: Chromanticore.author: CapmCrunch
378516: Chromanticore.text_parsed:
I want to say, "Whoa, weird multicolor card. How strange to put it in a two color set Wizards," but this is the least inspiring five color creature I've seen. Recently, there have been a lot of sets with an obligatory cycle of color lords, from the Mentors to the Maze Elementals. Chromanticore feels like an entire vanilla cycle jammed onto one card, none of the abilities feels very special because they've been overused to the point of boredom.

That said, this makes something huge. If there is a greedy hexproof deck still it wants to try to get this into play. While there isn't the awesome synergy that would have been first strike, deathtouch and trample; lifelink and vigilance mean that the manticore will be very hard to race once it does hit play.

It's really a shame this was designed in the no on board effects era. Looking at Cromat and knowing Chromaticore is a mythic manticore, it would have been cool to see what activated abilities they would give a five color version of a typically busted tribe. Regeneration and shooting, but what else?

For all of the people wondering how to get this out, just run a playset of Chromatic Lanterns.

378516: Chromanticore.author: Mode
378516: Chromanticore.text_parsed:
There are Mythics that are pushed beyond belief like Brimaz, King of Oreskos,
and then there are flavor-dripping Mythics that for some reason get the short end like this one.

This deserved to be so much more. Alone for the fact that it's a damn rainbow-powered Manticore.

It does have no protection from removal whatsoever, and - being an enchantment as well - is especially susceptile to it.
Unfortunately it didn't get haste as the red keyword either, so this might end up dead without having done anything.

Also, this would have been the ideal card to have a bestow cost equal to the casting cost.
Getting is one hell of a task. This isn't just something you throw in a deck and cast on turn five.
And being able to cast it for bestow that easily would have made up for the aforementioned fact with removal, since your opponent would at least have to deal twice with a threat when he doesn't have anything against enchantments.

You know, like Eidolon of Countless Battles. A much easier to cast three-drop with a bestow cost of four. Ugh! :/

It's a freaking WUBRG, make it at least a 5/5, for Heliod's sake!

378516: Chromanticore.author: DraftOnly
378516: Chromanticore.text_parsed:
I drafted this. Can you believe that this was passed 5 times? The fools...
Did I win? Hahaha, no. But I can guarantee you I had the most fun that night.

First game was lost.
Third game was also lost.
The second game was legendary.

I drew Chromanticore opening hand and had gotten enough to cast pretty early thanks to Unknown Shores and Opaline Unicorn, and it probably would've won then and there. I wanted to wait until I had enough mana to bestow it, however. I had a plan.

It was the most grueling 4 turns I've ever played. It was worth it.

I stood up and announced to the whole game store (20+ people that night):

"I bestow Chromanticore on Yoked Ox"

Best night of my life. 11/5 stars, would draft again.

(Incidentally, I went 2:0 that game. Topcarded Chromanticore as I was about to lose next turn. Yokedcore/Chromaticox 4 lyfe.)

378516: Chromanticore.author: Syrtees
378516: Chromanticore.text_parsed:
My local game store community and I wish this was legendary so we could play it as a commander (Because why not). Though, I believe Wizards did not want to have to deal with the rules complications between a legendary creature bestowed upon by a non-creature legendary with the same name (Though they probably just didn't have enough room in the typeline). Though that is an interesting interaction that should be analyzed.

"704.5k If a player controls two or more legendary permanents with the same name, that player chooses one of them, and the rest are put into their owners' graveyards. This is called the 'legend rule'."

Note that the rule doesn't care about whether or not the permanents are of the same type, only that they have the same name. What does this mean if this rule comes up (If, say, one of the players is using Leyline of Singularity)? You have a Chromanticore on the battlefield and get the ingenious idea to bestow a Chromanticore onto it. Upon resolution of the bestowing chromanticore you will be forced to choose one of them and sacrifice the other. If per chance you choose to keep the one that is bestowing then it will fall onto the field as a creature as the other is sacrificed. If you choose the other one, well, then it stays and the other is in the graveyard.

Kudos to you if you do pull off a Chromanticore with a Chromanticore on it, as redundant as that would be.

378517: Ephara, God of the Polis.author: Cloudchaser.Kestrel
378517: Ephara, God of the Polis.text_parsed:
You can take Ephara's flavor a couple different ways - I enjoy them all.

Whenever a creature enters - this refers to the growth of the Polis, as babies are born Ephara gains power - she learns from each mortal as they grow and mature so that durring the next upkeep she has learned enough to draw you a card.

- Alternately this refers to whenever a creature comes of age and enters the polis as an adult - as we know parasophia is part of the Polis (gods I hope we get a Parasophia card) - and she learns from each new student as they explore and learn. Ephara is the embodiment of this learning and so draws you a card as new arguments enter the great conversation that is Meletis.

I've been proxying this in my gift of immortality, sacrifice deck (burnished hart and trading post) and its beautiful.

Also note akroan horse, and heliod, god of the sun as consistent creature sources on your opponent's turn.

378517: Ephara, God of the Polis.author: Enelysios
378517: Ephara, God of the Polis.text_parsed:
@K34: Drawing a card every upkeep for 4 mana would be insane. Making it indestructible and sometimes a creature? I suspect that would be banned or restricted in every major format. This triggers on every player's turn, not just yours. Mythic doesn't just mean powerful, it means unique and flashy. Its not an excuse to make a card broken.

I think this and Karametra are the two most powerful gods for EDH. Blue/white and flicker are already strong in EDH, and now I can draw a card on each of my opponent's turns as long as I can flicker or flash in a creature? I am sure my opponents are going to hate me, all you need to break this is a Deadeye Navigator and some ETB effects. Luminate Primordial anyone?

378517: Ephara, God of the Polis.author: SAUS3
378517: Ephara, God of the Polis.text_parsed:
@TheWallinator74
I don't think this is for white weenie decks. You definitely want to run those style of creatures in a deck running this card, but it would ultimately be a slower deck. It'd probably feature more removal and control elements while running creatures that help control and also dish out damage - like lyev skyknight for example as well as maybe banisher priest.

Devotion would be important and some ways to get creatures into play on your opponent's turns would be handy. Ephara would act as a finisher and would keep your hand full while you continually drop threats and answers.

378518: Ephara's Enlightenment.author: Linkcharge
378518: Ephara's Enlightenment.text_parsed:
@SkyknightXi
No. The +1/+1 counter doesn't eliminate the existing -1/-1 counter. The creature ends up with both. They cancel each other out with regards to power and toughness values, but the counters aren't removed from the creature.

When the persist creature dies the second time, it has a -1/-1 counter on it, so persists doesn't trigger. The presence of a +1/+1 counter doesn't change that.

378518: Ephara's Enlightenment.author: Nancymaker
378518: Ephara's Enlightenment.text_parsed:
@Linkcharge
You're 100% incorrect. Persist creatures are, in fact, reset by putting +1/+1 counters on them.

'121.3. If a permanent has both a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 and N -1/-1 counters
are removed from it as a state-based action, where N is the smaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters on it. See rule 704. '

So Ephara's Enlightenment would work as suggested by SkyknightXi.
378518: Ephara's Enlightenment.text_posted:
@Linkcharge
You're 100% incorrect. Persist creatures are, in fact, reset by putting +1/+1 counters on them.

'121.3. If a permanent has both a +1/+1 counter and a -1/-1 counter on it, N +1/+1 and N -1/-1 counters
are removed from it as a state-based action, where N is the smaller of the number of +1/+1 and -1/-1 counters on it. See rule 704. '

So Ephara's Enlightenment would work as suggested by SkyknightXi.

378518: Ephara's Enlightenment.author: Opeth2010
378518: Ephara's Enlightenment.text_parsed: As fun and exciting as the idea of Heroic is, the reality is that the mechanic, as well as this card kind of suck. They are designed for the limited format. Sure, I could play a Battlewise Hoplite and then make it 4/4 flier with this card the following turn, but I'd much rather make a 3/3 for 2, put a counter on it with Ajani, Caller of the Pride, and then give it flying double strike the following turn, possibly for the win. Or just skip the counter and throw the 3/3 double strike over the top right away. My point is, they just didn't make Heroic good enough to have any constructed application. Why bother going through all the trouble and wasting all your mana and spells trying to put counters on a crappy 1/1 or 2/2 heroic creature when you can simply play a 3/3 for 2 mana, a 4/4 for 3, or a 5/5 for 4. By the time you'd actually be able to get a heroic creature beyond that point, you should have won already. You can take all those "heroic trigger" spells, such as this one, and replace them with other 3/3 for 2, 4/4 for 3 etc creatures.

378519: Fanatic of Xenagos.author: PopcornBunni
378519: Fanatic of Xenagos.text_parsed:
This is the kind of guy that makes me think Wizards are trying to see how much the creature curve can bend safely. I think everyone is perfectly fine letting most of the tribute creatures get their counters, since they have no protection against the myriad of cost-efficient removal available. As spells get a bit weaker over time and creatures push the power curve, I feel that game balance will eventually get to a point where non-protected creatures and spells are on the same level.

It'll be interesting to see how these guys do next standard, with cards like putrefy and dreadbore out.

Other than that, Tribute has great flavor, and occasionally wonderful playability.

378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.author: Chrysemys
378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.text_parsed: @MageofVoid I think that the reason everyone is disappointed is because she doesn't really do what Selesnya players want to be doing, at least in Standard. Right now Selesnya beatdown is a pretty quick deck and five mana is usually about when the Boon Satyrs start getting deployed and the Fleecemane Lions start getting popped and your hand is next to empty after releasing all those efficient threats, not when the need for more mana arises. Sure, she seems fine for a deck that wants to crank out seven and eight-drops to finish out a game but she really doesn't fit in as a finisher, as far as her godly land-fetching ability is concerned, with a deck primarily run by three and four-drops.

378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.author: Shivan_Raptor
378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.text_parsed:
I do believe the criticism is grounded in many players understanding of the speed of the game from the last few sets. You have to admit by the time you're casting our great god of G/W here, your opponent probably has all the mana he'll need to win. Granted I'm not a great player or anything, but land ramping at 5 CMC seems kinda redundant. Then again Primeval Titan is considered good, but hes a creature all the time. I suppose one could acknowledge the fact the game is being forced to slow down, which if true is great as I'd love to get a Worldspine Wurm and use it competitively some day.

My biggest gripe with it, though, is the requirement to have it be a creature. Seven is big number and there aren't many solid options for this guy to team up with. Selensya colors hurt it a bit too, as thats more about the tokens right now, and they don't have any devotion to give.

Over all landfall decks might use this god to great effect, while the general playerbase shuns in for other more straightforward choices.

378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.author: troll_berserker
378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.text_parsed:
Very poor and conflicting design. You want to hold on to your mana dorks in your hand until turn 6 so you can actually use Karametra's effect to ramp. But by doing that, you sacrifice your ability to ramp with the dorks in the first place. Plus the lands come in tapped, so you play your creatures turn 6 and can't even use that extra mana until turn 7!

The casuals saying this is a 4/5 card are living in a magical Christmas land in which the opponent doesn't play aggro and kill you before turn 5, or doesn't play control and Dissolve or Detention Sphere the god. GW players should stick to turn 1 Elvish Mystic, turn 2 Loxodon Smiter if they want to win games.

378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.author: Toraka
378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.text_parsed:
So...
The Acolytes that my R/G/U deck has been tapping for 10 mana each for months now actually belong to a G/W god?

Huh.
Card, right. Well, she IS rather narrow, but she brings you past those cursed missing land draws when you just cast her and are holding your big 6 drop. (For instance, a Ravager.) I suppose my deck is as good a place for her as any. That deck generates whatever mana it wants anyway and there's never too much mana.

Actually, interesting combo: Prophet of Kruphix + Garruk's Horde + Karametra + an abundant mana base (which I have). You can instant speed cast off the top card of your library, then keep stacking creatures until you hit a land or a creature you don't want. Then, let Karametra's trigger resolve, shuffle up, and continue. Also, you can peek at the top card in between shuffles, so you can decline shuffling if you hit a nice creature without the mana to cast it.

378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.author: Raynfal
378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.text_parsed:
Something worth noting for anyone using her with Landfall:
Since her ability is triggered on creature cast--rather than creature ETB--casting a Landfall creature, like Rampaging Baloths, will have you fetch a Forest or Plains while the creature is still on the stack and not yet on the battlefield. Casting the creature won't end up causing its own Landfall ability to trigger off of itself through Karametra. It'll have to wait for another creature to be cast afterward.
378520: Karametra, God of Harvests.text_posted:
Something worth noting for anyone using her with Landfall:
Since her ability is triggered on creature cast--rather than creature ETB--casting a Landfall creature, like [autocard]Rampaging Baloths[/autocard], will have you fetch a Forest or Plains while the creature is still on the stack and not yet on the battlefield.  Casting the creature won't end up causing its own Landfall ability to trigger off of itself through Karametra.  It'll have to wait for another creature to be cast afterward.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: hypa_dude
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed:
I pulled this in a draft last night, and it plays even better than it looks, especially in limited.

The +1 essentially locks your opponent down. If you fog their best creature, it makes it very difficult for them to profitably attack, so getting her to 5 is actually quite easy.

The -1 is ok, but because it is a -1 there are very few game states where this ability is actually useful. By turn 4, you're only using this if you've been flooded for the rest of the game and need another card, or if you have another land (your fifth of the game) AND a 5 or 6 drop that is better than a 9/9 token every turn (Is there such a thing?). Remember, if you don't have enough lands in your hand to play the extra land, moving away from ultimate doesn't really make the extra card worthwhile. When I first saw this card spoiled, I thought the -1 was the best ability, but . .

The -5 is a game winner. Sweepers, spot removal, bouncing, etc really only stem the tide of your army of 9/9's.

I only drew it once in all of my games, but when I did, it easily won me the game. My only gripe is that she starts at 2, so she is pretty easy for burn to kill on her first two turns out. 4/5.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: SirLibraryEater
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed:
Can we all take a second to appreciate that R&D finally printed a {G}{U} planeswalker?
And that she's super good? Any planeswalker with a way to protect itself, like her +1 ability kinda does, can be broken. And with an ultimate like that that leaves Timmies drooling, why not make it a thing in Standard?
I mean, at the very least, she's two Explores on one card for {2}{G}{U}. That's like extra card advantage because you don't have to play 2 cards.
My Vorel of the Hull Clade EDH deck will never be the same(and NOT because they can interact, I recognize they can't).

-ALSO-
A little speculation here, but I think the next block after Theros might be another block set in Zendikar. Here's why:
There was an article on DailyMTG this morning, a flavorful one(here it is:http://www.wizards.com/magic/magazine/article.aspx?x=mtg/daily/ur/286), about how Kiora got to Theros. It says:
"Zendikar.
Home. She longed to return to her own world, with its wild and cantankerous temperament. Most worlds were whales—elegant, peaceful, toothless. Zendikar was a shark, and it had been too long since she'd swum in the presence of its power.
But she couldn't return to Zendikar. Not yet. Not without a weapon to fight the monstrosities called the Eldrazi. And so her search continued."
Maybe the sea monsters Kiora finds on Theros will be the weapon she needs. Maybe she intends to go back to Zendikar, in all its broken glory.
And maybe Xenagos, arguably the most powerful planeswalker as he is a God, will tag along and be the new Bolas-esque villain of Magic.

-LASTLY-
To reference Duels of the Planeswalkers, maybe a Ral Zarek vs. Kiora Atua duel decks?

@MattyWayne - It can, but it won't do damage to or take damage from the attacking creature.

@fibonacci - I'm not from NZ, I'm a skip, but that's the first thing I noticed too.

As for the card, I think it's an elegant design. Plenty of upside but not OP. I thought the "target permanent" was pretty cheeky, took me a sec to figure out just what other type of permanent is going to take damage :P

It is a shame that she's boltbait, but landing that emblem makes you dangerous for the rest of the game regardless of what happens.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: jlbyellin
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed:
Man, she's so good. I run her in my Bant Superfriends Control deck, and she's just so amazingly versatile. You can use her to ramp, you can use her to shut down an opponent's threat, and if you activate her ultimate, you have a 95% chance of winning the game (if the opponent actually sticks around and doesn't scoop).

Her low loyalty isn't as much of a problem as I would have thought when I first saw her. If you think you're opponent isn't going to let her survive until your next turn, just use her -1 and let him or her waste an attack/burn spell/Hero's Downfall on her. If she happens to survive until your next turn, you get a free Explore, and if you're running four of these in your deck, you'll hopefully draw another one soon after the first one departs.

What makes Planeswalkers good is their versatility, and with that, Kiora is one of the better walkers in Standard right now. Just wait until Kruphix hits the scene with Journey into Nyx.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: FarisV
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed: I was really busy and trying to cut back on spending so much on cards when Born first came out, but last time I went to the card shop in my town my two friends and I split a booster box, and out of my share of 12 packs I got two of these ladies. She's (both are) in my BUG proliferate deck, and although I've only gotten to use her twice, I managed to build up both and use all their loyalty for the ultimate, thanks to some simple proliferate and overkill Magistrate's Scepter. Having two 9/9 kraken tokens appear before their turn, every turn, just felt awesome. Very, very happy to see a simic planeswalker, and even more in disbelief I got two . Lot's of fun, great great card to play and doesn't require much building around to be useful - any strong blue and green could probably benefit from at the very least her +1 -1 abilities, and the ultimate is always a nice threat to go for. 4/5 easily.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: Layk
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed: Too much praise for this card. On paper it looks bad. She can nullify ONE attacker (enchantment, artifact, etc.) (while making an invincible blocker in the same turn) and she's very easy to kill. Let's say you drop her turn 3, you're probably waiting until turn 6 to use her ultimate, unless you have some sort of other shenanigans going on (inb4 "hurr durr proliferate", for those of you who say it whenever a card reads "counter"). If you want to keep her around, turn 7. Though this isn't one of those planeswalkers you really need to keep around, her ult is pretty powerful. I think her only redeeming quality is her -1 ability, though you can only use this ONCE before needing to recharge, and it's not worth charging JUST for this ability, so therefore it isn't worth dropping 4 on her for that. Altogether, 3.5/5

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: jonrds
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed:
People don't like her because she doesn't make a huge impact as soon as she hits the table, but what she excels at is forcing your opponent to make bad moves.
Her +1 locks down your opponent's best (or most evasive) creature and makes them work to get her off the table. I've played plenty of games against her where I've had to swing with an elvish mystic or something just to have enough creatures to stop her from ulting.
Her -1 is useful. Makes her not a dead draw even when you aren't controlling the board well enough or won't be able to protect her from a lightning strike. It especially goes well with Courser of Kruphix.
Her ult is absolutely ridiculous. If you manage to get it off, you are pretty much guaranteed the game. And its an emblem, so it keeps being useful and there is nothing they can do about it.

I'd argue that what makes her cool is that her ult is the scariest part about her. Normally the ults are win-more, never going to happen, or underwhelming. Definitely not the case for her. You often hear about things attracting removal. She demands it.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: OlvynChuru
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed:
Kiora is a great card. Keep in mind that, although she starts out with low loyalty, she only starts three counters away from her ultimate, which is game-winning. This means that she works amazing with Clockspinning, which she actually curves perfectly into. Consider this example:

Turn 4
Land, Kiora, use the +1 on the opponent's most dangerous creature.

Turn 5
Land, Clockspinning on Kiora with buyback, Clockspinning on Kiora without buyback, use Kiora's -5 ability. GG.

In the right deck, Kiora is amazing.

4.5/5

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: mdakw576
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed:
She's very bad against decks with multiple small creatures and especially lightning strike. Boros burn is an example of a horrendous matchup for Kiora; tons of small creatures and a 3-point burn spell that can kill her even after a +1. Explore is also not a particularly useful effect against aggro, since your whole gameplan against aggro is to gain life and kill their stuff. She's also quite bad against mutavault, and while you can say that for a lot of planeswalkers, Kiora's issues are magnified because of the low starting loyalty (yes, she can bubble the mutavault, but often the opponent has other stuff on the board).

However she's great against everything else. Against midrange-decks like monoblack devotion, unless they stick a pack rat or hero's downfall the kiora, they often have trouble deploying multiple threats quickly, and the +1 is great at neutralizing a desecration demon or nightveil specter.

Against control she's just as good as any other walker, where grinding out control decks involves hitting your land drops and drawing cards. In addition, unless the opponent has mutavault out, they often won't have a creature out to swing at kiora, so they would need to spend a dsphere/pithing needle/etc. to stop her.

Kiora will never be broken in standard unless red decks are so bad they won't exist, because lightning strike is such a good answer to her. But once mutavault rotates out of standard, I expect Kiora to become better. Boros charm and skullcrack will also be going out too and we'll have to wait to see what other burn spells wizards will print.

In EDH, she's a decent political card. There are many cards that can deal a lot of damage (Nekusar, Purphoros, generals, etc) and you can stem the bleeding and maybe try to make a truce with the other players to let her keep bubbling the most damaging card. If your playgroup has no idea how to play politics though, she won't survive long.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed: I had been trying to figure out if there was any significance to why the tokens were specifically 9/9s. Then it hit me, Kiora's artwork is inspired by the famous painting of waves. The number 9 is shaped like a wave, and the constant flow of a 9/9 on each of your ends steps is like the tide itself.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: TheWrathofShane
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed:
Her +1 does not have any immediate board impact or card advantage generator. But it does fantastic job of protecting herself against creatures.

Her -1 is very weak when compared to other walkers bribe abilities. Lets compare it with a simple spell like consecrate. With consecrate you get an immediate bang of 3 cards. With kiora -1, you get only 1 card and then are sitting at a fragile 1 counter. Consecrate seems like the safer play here...

Her ultimate can be very powerful, a 9/9 every turn is more then enough for a win condition, and it fits her theme and flavor perfectly.

There are three ways to go about playing her. You can either +1 spam to build up for ultimate, go for double -1, or oscillate between -1 and +1.

If you are just spamming +1 you are vulnerable to many forms of planeswalker removal without generating any bang for your buck, a true 1 for 1 trade. Where as with another walker you would have gotten some mileage for your buildup ability.

If you go for double -1, I feel other walkers have much stronger bribe abilities. Like I said even if you get the double explore, a simple spell like consecrate is subjectively better.

If you try to oscillate, while she is an engine, I believe you are better off just going with Jace, Memory Adept and sticking with +1. You get a card every turn and build up towards an ultimate.


While I shelled out the tickets for three copies, mostly because its a simic walker, I feel the pricetag will indeed drop and that she is not that strong compared to other planeswalkers. Still I am having fun with her and have won a couple of games with Unleash the Krakens.

378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.author: Drewskithelegend
378521: Kiora, the Crashing Wave.text_parsed: I didn't think I would ever say this, but I think she is in the running for one of the top 5 planeswalkers ever. If it weren't for that awkward second ability, it would be a definite yes. She is well costed, evasive, and she hits your opponent like a truck when she goes ultimate. Like I said though, her second ability is meh. I wouldn't want to use it immediately because it would leave her loyalty low enough to kill with pretty much anything and I wouldn't want to plus her a couple times and then use it because her -5 is so amazing. If it had allowed for draw 2 or something similar, it would have been ok.

If it weren't for that awkward second ability, it would be a definite yes. She is well costed, evasive, and she hits your opponent like a truck when she goes ultimate. Like I said though, her second ability is meh. I wouldn't want to use it immediately because it would leave her loyalty low enough to kill with pretty much anything and I wouldn't want to plus her a couple times and then use it because her -5 is so amazing. If it had allowed for draw 2 or something similar, it would have been ok.

378522: Kiora's Follower.author: BegleOne
378522: Kiora's Follower.text_parsed:
This is a decent pauper EDH general if nothing else.

Perhaps the best infinite loop to assemble in the format is a land that taps for 2-4 mana (Simic Growth Chamber, Fertile Growth, Verdant Haven, Dawn's Reflection, et cetera) paired with a land untapper (Krosan Restorer, Voyaging Satyr, Stone-Seeder Hierophant) paired with a creature untapper (Freed from the Real, Galvanic Alchemist). It's one of very limited infinite combos that has redundancy in each component, and it's in two colors that can assemble it. (Drift of Phantasms, Commune with the Gods, Frantic Search)


This card is in the proper colors and serves as a part of the combo.

(Its competition in its colors is the Gilder Bairn and Pentad Prism infinite mana combo.)

378522: Kiora's Follower.author: Ferlord
378522: Kiora's Follower.text_parsed:
@ DeckMechanic, it can't target itself. It says "Another target permanent", implying anything but this. If you had two of them, that could work.

Otherwise, this is a beast in limited. When you're looking at your opponents untapped lands, you don't think about this as a source of mana at first.

For example, I was playing a guy who played this on turn two. He didn't play a land on turn 3, and he didn't play anything. "Excellent", I thought. "I can play Fabled Hero and still have the to pay for Stymied Hopes". I didn't consider him technically having 3 mana for Dissolve, since it just looks like he's got 2 untapped mana.

The best combat trick is this and Pheres-Band Tromper. If you attack with the tromper and they have a 3/3 to block, they'll block it. It sucks for them because now your tromper's a 4/4... and it's untapped.

A definite champion of this set.

378522: Kiora's Follower.author: Clietus
378522: Kiora's Follower.text_parsed:
Yes, yes, infinite loops in standard, but more importantly, how does he actually swim? That huuuuuge fin he has on the back of his head makes swimming look incredibly impractical. From what I can tell, he has four methods to swim, any of which make him look goofy to his fellow merfolk:

A.) He swims with his face constantly pointed downwards, which doesn't seem like he'd ever be able to see where he's going, and the fin doesn't look designed for that type of swimming anyway,

B.) He swims vertically, which is either intimidating or hilarious, depending on your politics,

C.) He arches his spine in ways that shouldn't be arched to properly allow the fin not to get in his way of his torso or legs,

D.) He folds the fin to the side as he swims. I'm no marine biologist, but I think a curved fin would always make him swim lopsided.

378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.author: Drewskithelegend
378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.text_parsed:
Anybody who says this is bad is either trolling or has no idea what they are saying. While unlikely to kill somebody with the 2 alone each turn, that shock can certainly add up and at the very least prove detrimental to decks running Lifegain. I see him more as a 7/5 indestructible for 4, which is absolutely insane. The fact that he will be doing something even if devotion is below 7 is just an added benefit.Don't get me wrong, if left unchecked, the damage or die effect is very good, especially in limited but potentially in constructed midrange-y decks as well. Playing this at the prerelease, I had a guy at 5 pay down to 3 and then die to Lightning Strike. That's part of what I like so much about this card. Things like Boros Reckoner, Guttersnipe, Cinder Elemental,Stormbreath Dragon and whatnot are big and urgent and demand answers quickly. 2 is small enough that it doesn't seem that urgent and is absolutely favorable to sacrificing creatures. Subtle but powerful and well-rounded.
I'm definitely going to have to give this a 4.5/5.

378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.author: EyesOfSyrus
378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.text_parsed:
This is how im going to use him in my red/black aggro deck.
Fill the deck with just quick duel mana drops like Rakdos Cackler, Goblin Deathraiders, Spike Jester and Fists of the Demigod

Turn 1: mountain, tap Rakdos Cackler
Turn 2: Swamp, tap out for Goblin Deathraiders
Turn 3: Mountain, tap for Fists of the Demigod on Goblin Deathraiders for a 5/3 first strike, trample, wither.
Turn 4: Swamp, tap out for an active Mogis, God of Slaughter
Turn 5: Another Fists of the Demigod on Mogis, God of Slaughter for a 9/7 indestructible, first strike, wither.

Granted this is a perfect opening hand and draws each turn. But on turn 5 that's a scary bored to look at. It could be a turn 5 win if your hitting him every turn. Sure you could kill the Goblin Deathraiders with a Doom blade or something. But every turn you will be dropping something to keep Mogis, God of Slaughter up and going.

378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.author: ArannisNalaar
378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.text_parsed:
@EyesOfSyrus, none of your logic works.

First of all, hybrid mana symbols like those in Rackdos Cackler and Fists of the Demigod only count for 1 devotion because they are one symbol. Thus that example you gave would only be a total of 6 devotion.

Secondly, Doom Blade can't kill Goblin Deathraiders because it is black. Doom Blade only kills nonblack creatures.

Also don't forget that if Mogis, God of Slaughter loses his creature type, any Enchant creature auras will fall off and go to the graveyard.

378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.author: DarthParallax
378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.text_parsed:
Thanks to Demons, Dragons, Enchantments, and 2- and 3-drop Red Creatures, this is by far going to be the Easiest and Most Painful God to Manifest out of all 15, which I say even before seeing the last 5.


Demigod of Revenge is one of the least imaginative ways to do it. (And more effective than Divinity of Pride if your deck is managing to run a full 4 and a nice Reanimation Trick!

Rakdos, the Defiler will probably be one of the more often-seen ways to do it in EDH. I think that card finishes the job all on it's own as well?

Anyway, literally, most of the cards you want to play, simply two-card combo with Mogis for his Devotion count. Black-Red is more Mana-Dense than just about anything.

I know, I know, it's said too much in reference to ''put next to really big guns in Red and Black", but ACTUALLY, this IS a card that Kaalia of the Vast players may want to diversify into: It's really important for a deck that has a critical strength, to cover it so it doesn't become a critical-weakness. I don't know how much Anti-Tribal (not just hate a specific Tribe-- anti-Tribal- let's you choose which Tribe you Hate) hate there is, but really almost ANY amount that is ever printed could become a HUGE problem for Kaalia decks.

I've frequently suggested Titans as something that people might enjoy as considerations, but Gods may work much better for what Kaalia Decks want. You wouldn't want to ''waste'' too many cards doing something off the beaten path of what your General tells you to do, but if you see two in particular that SCREAM at you "Whoah, this would actually eat face", well that's different.

I think Mogis and Athreos will do this for Kaalia.

@Koenneo: The card is still indestructible because only the card type changes, not the text. However, there's nothing that stops you from using a card like Erase on it, and you can still use it on him if he's a creature because he never stops being an enchantment.

378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.author: JailedWanderer
378523: Mogis, God of Slaughter.text_parsed: Quite a few of the gods that they released and are spoiling interestingly fit well in a grixis control deck. Mogis has the ability to kill enemy creatures or punch people in the face, Keranos can draw you extra cards or punch people in the face, Erebos can draw you extra cards, and Thassa can get threats through as well as well as generate card advantage. The other gods that fit into control colors really don't help a creatureless control deck. Ephara, and atheros are useless unless you have creatures to play. I haven't looked at other cards that would work in these colors, but from this perspective we may see grixis control as sphinxes revelation and other ravinca cards rotate out of standard.

378524: Phenax, God of Deception.author: MageofVoid
378524: Phenax, God of Deception.text_parsed: As a player that even enjoys playing mill, it's bothersome when they devote mythics to it but don't print any at the commons level. It makes good mill decks expensive to play in constructed and nearly impossible in limited. The problem with mill is that it is it's own unique deck type, separate from any other, you really will never have any reason to put milling cards in a non-milling deck. And, similarly to land destruction, wizards has shown that they really don't want milling to be prevalent and good in the metagame, they seemingly just want to keep it around for novelty's sake, except rares and mythics don't get wasted on land destruction.

378524: Phenax, God of Deception.author: MisterAction
378524: Phenax, God of Deception.text_parsed:
I don't have a problem with mill. And this looks very powerful. But isn't my favorite color pair for its power. It's for all the flavorful, varied, elegant and downright insanely cool cards that result when blue and black intersect.

Given that Lazav was a straight-up love letter to everything blue and black does, ideal for mill but also good with countering, sacrifices, discard and kill spells, and cipher was an awesome mechanic (even if it had to be understandably weak), yes I am disappointed that our patron god is "Just an insanely powerful manaless repeatable mill effect attached to a huge cheap indestructible creature." It's *very* good, but it doesn't have that blue-black swagger.

Yes, Phenax is really powerful, it's really ridiculous mill. Awesome. I'm pretty sure I'm not the only blue black mage out there who actually likes combat and wants to participate in it and you know...not sit behind walls and mill my opponent to death.
So why is this the God of Deception? The best thing I can come up with is this: the fact that mill decks snap 4 of this guy as soon as they can is obvious. The mill is just too effective not to...however, since it is so effective...it enables mill for non-mill decks, too. By that I mean, finally we have a very good, repeatable mill effect on a pretty sturdy stick for our blue black decks that -don't- necessarily use mill as their win condition, but just use the graveyards as a resource. Mill stuff for your Rise from the Grave effects. Mill stuff for your Memory Plunder or Psychic Intrusion. This card enables graveyard shenanigans like no other in a neat package, saving you lots of card slots that you would have otherwise used for all the random mill cards out there just to enable your other effects.
Even after that though, I think I'm still a little disappointed in this. It's slow - for this is yet another blocker against the creatures you see these days. It does nothing when you have no creatures of your own and let's face it is a color combination that finds itself in that position quite often. And I still don't think deception means milling :P

378524: Phenax, God of Deception.author: infernox10
378524: Phenax, God of Deception.text_parsed:
I like Phenax. He's a pretty cool guy. I like what he's got goin on.
I'm not doubting his power.
What I MAINLY complain about is how not creative he is.
Blue/Black has some crazy shenanigans going for it:
Lim-Dûl's Vault
Countersquall
Dimir Infiltrator
Recoil
Shadow of Doubt
Silent-Blade Oni
Undermine
That's just SOME of the vast amount of what this color combination has to offer.
In addition to all this, blue/black has had a reputation for being the "main mill color combination", which is well-deserved, I'll admit.
BUT MILL DOES NOT DEFINE THIS COLOR COMBINATION'S IDENTITY.
So when Wizards tells the community that there are Gods that are meant to be embodiments of these color pairs, people get really excited. These are GODS of these colors. They show what these color combinations are all about, what they'll mean to the community henceforth. THEY EVEN NAME HIM GOD OF DECEPTION! THAT'S SO FREAKIN' COOL!!!
But, instead of any weird, funky, neat thing that they could come up with, they just slap a powerful mill clause on him and call it a day.
That's where the backlash comes from.
Not from his "lack of power"; Phenax is plenty powerful.
Not from "mill isn't viable"; casual players love alternate win-cons, and mill is prominent with them.
It's from the let-down of knowing that this color-combination's embodiment is mill. The knowledge that blue/black is now NOT solidified as deceptive and incrementally advantageous, but INSTEAD simplified into "the mill colors".

378524: Phenax, God of Deception.author: Enelysios
378524: Phenax, God of Deception.text_parsed:
I like mill, I play a dedicated mill deck. However, this god is just boring, as is the style of play it encourages. He is incredibly straight forward, not the god of deception in any way! He want you to play walls, defend and counter, then tap all your junk at the end of your opponent's turn. This is slow, and non-interactive and predictable. It is the opposite of the effect a god of deception would have on the battlefield! Ephara, God of the Polis may be pure white/blue, but she still feels more deceptive than he does with her flash and blink antics.

I guess the flavor they were going with was that your seemingly un-threatening creatures can kill? Still, this god reeks of missed opportunity. He is powerful but boring, which is sad because that art is amazing! Look for the larger version in the wallpaper archives!

I would have preferred an effect that shows real deception, even if it was less powerful. Some ideas: "If a spell or effect you control would cause an opponent to make a decision, you make that decision for that player.", "Opponents play with their hands revealed. You may look at face down cards your opponents own, and any cards in an opponent's library he or she looks at." or ": You may cast target instant or sorcery card in an opponent's graveyard this turn." How about "Whenever a creature enters the battlefield under an opponent's control, you may exchange control of it and target non-token creature you control." Maybe "Whenever a permanent is returned to its owner's hand, that player discards a card." I will admit, some of these are probably too odd or technical, but there are just tons of interesting effects in Blue/black and its a shame they went with such a straight forward card for what should be the least straight forward god.

378524: Phenax, God of Deception.author: The_USAgent
378524: Phenax, God of Deception.text_parsed:
Dear WotC,

PLEASE STOP forcing Blue/Black mill.
I know players like milling someone out but its getting old.
Don't get me wrong, I enjoy mill but this is starting to get ridiculous.
Please go back to cards like Recoil, Undermine, Agony Warp, Diabolic Vision.

Out of the 20 U/B legendary creatures: 5 are mill, 2 are mill dependent, 8 are unplayable (all the old bordered ones are bad), the other 5 have various degrees of playability.
I'm not saying get rid of mill forever just give it a break for a while, please.

378524: Phenax, God of Deception.author: kor6sic6
378524: Phenax, God of Deception.text_parsed:
I run this god as a one-of in my current Standard BUG list, along with one Thassa (soon to be a one-of Kruphix as well), and this guy packs a whallop. The deck packs a ton of removal and answers to other control decks. Also, no one expects him late game, so dropping him down and then decking your opponent on the spot always feels good.

I also participated in an unsanctioned four-man draft recently, and this guy was my rare-slot in pack one. I'm a U/B Timmy/Johnny by nature, so this was an easy pick one. No one else ended up drafting my colors, so the slate was open for me. I didn't end up winning overall, but I did mill two separate opponent during my matches. Felt good, man.

It has flavour. IN SPADES. . This is no fun to play against, and I wouldn't play this because it's no fun to play with either. At least to my mind at any rate. I play this colour combo to have fun, and mill ain't much fun. UB deserves better role models than this, it's just a damn shame is all.

378525: Ragemonger.author: Nucleon
378525: Ragemonger.text_parsed:
I can't actually think of any other cost-reduction cards that both lessen colored mana and allow you to drop the cost below 1. Free stuff is not something Wizards lets us play with often short of Kobolds, Ornithopter, and Memnite (Yeah, yeah, and Shield Sphere and others, I know). With good reason, given that whole Affinity thing and how that turned out. Or, on the spells side, Storm. Things we get to cast for little to no mana investment are dangerous stuff.

Still, great self-synergy and external synergy, for sure. Being able to play one, then drop another for 1 colorless is pretty crazy, and then you get to the other guys he pours out.

Aluren is already busted in half, but if you want to play some sort of kitchen-table black-eye simulator, go for it the same way particularly abusive Animar decks do.

Also, a convoluted use for Conspiracy and any myriad color-swapping Blue spells.

378527: Siren of the Silent Song.author: BobbySinclair
378527: Siren of the Silent Song.text_parsed:
Going straight in my Zombie Mill EDH, for several reasons:

1) Flying zombies are super rare. There are enough zombie lords out there to make this guy a legitimate attacking force, and that in turn enables the Inspired mechanic.

2) Cheap for EDH, but a powerful mechanic, particularly with the discard. Can easily be gotten out on turn 2 most times with EDH ramp, and the sudden swing in card advantage could be enough to tip early game balance, or at least get your opponents to waste a valuable removal on it.

3) Awesome combos within its colours. Namely, Intruder Alarm. Cryptic Gateway with that in zombie tribal is just a joke. Add in other cards like Hair-strung Koto and Phenax, God of Deception, and you've got a synergy that works with both tapping AND untapping your creatures, for the perfect mill combinations.

Sure another toughness would have been awesome, but it's still really good for its cost. Definitely going straight in my deck when I get my hands on one!

378527: Siren of the Silent Song.author: TopRomen
378527: Siren of the Silent Song.text_parsed:
Need some fun ways to get this chick tapped?

Mothdust changeling allows you to safely get her tapped the very turn she comes out, as does Bramblesnap - both at instant speed, too!

My FAVORITE card with her though is Hidden Strings. If I've put her out since last turn and my opponent can't block flying, play it (tap the siren, untap the siren), cipher strings to your siren, swing at your enemy for two, play hidden strings again (untap the siren, tap her again), and then after their turn ends, she untaps to discard another card - 3 mill and 3 discard, with 2 more each turn if they don't do anything about it.

And yah, having Phenax is just icing at that point.

378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.author: Drewskithelegend
378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.text_parsed:
And lo, Xenagos ascended to godhood, and the revelry of the satyr orgies did increase tenfold. All throughout Theros, bands of satyrs engaging in revels could be heard chanting "Hail Xenagod, god of teh lulz!" And Xenagod smiled upon his kin with a smug, cheese eating grin and he sang...
"Now this is a story all about how Theros was flipped turned upside-down and I'd like to take a minute just wait and see how I became god of revelries.

In the skola valley born and raised
where we satyrs waste most of our days
partying drinking enslaving some guys
and suddenly to everyone's surprise I disappeared, left the plane
took a few months then came back again.
I was a planeswalker now and I got bored
and I said
'I think I wanna become the party god instead'

I tried and failed day after day
but just couldn't seem to figure out a way
so I got some monsters and with a nod I declared all out war against the gods.

The gods yo they couldn't bear
Every city's polis was in a state of disrepair
So they called on some planeswalker chick named Elspeth
To try to end my crusade of destruction and death

But wait, I think this is all for the best
Perhaps the gods should be put to the test
But they don't think so
What do they know
I hope they're prepared for the new god of Theros

Well uh a bunch of soldiers and their planeswalker friend
Stood Calling for my deposition
For my campaign to end
I ain't giving up that easy
I'm in this too far
So I sent an army to make it hard.

That's right I called a bunch of minotaurs here
Rounded them up like heads of steer
If anything I'd say my hoarde was dope
And so my other plan's success was my hope

My Minotaur army did face defeat
But At that point I said "yo homes I don't need ya"
I'd become a god,
A divine devil
To join the Theros pantheon as the god of revels."


@Hunter06 I was just thinking the same thing. After checking the backstory (because it's not everyday a less notable planeswalker suddenly turns into a god) it says the conditions of the transformation are a mystery at this time. Also it mentions how he became aware of his insignificance after planeswalking around a bit. Knowing how NB has made a disciple of Sarkhan, RG is clearly a color combo he could be considered affiliated with. If Bolas is behind it all, could we have at least one 3+ color god or, heck, a new Bolas planeswalker? He's been a little too quiet IMO...

378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.author: DarthParallax
378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.text_parsed:
OK- what if Xengaos is actually just an Innocent Victim in all of this? We could be blowing this 'Stole Power from the Gods' thing waaayyy out of proportion-- Imagine:
You're just a really fun guy, a party animal in school, and all your friends just LIKE you.

Nex thing you know- they start a cult around you and start sacrificing goats and having orgies in your honor. Well, wouldn't you be tempted to just kind of....live it up and let them carry on?

For this one, I had to branch out from Disney and hit up DreamWorks- hope you all don't mind :)

XENAGOS, GOD OF REVELS' LAMENT- HOW TO SUCCEED AT BLASPHEMY WITHOUT REALLY TRYING.

"I Hardly Think I'm qualified
To come across all sanctified
I just don't cut it with the cherubim.

Kiora Atua: Xenagos, what are you talking about?


There Again! :O They're on their knees O:|
Being Worshipped Is A Breeze :D
Which rather suits us in the interim! ^ O ^

Kiora, The Crashing Wave: In-terim, In-terim, It's me and him!

IT'S TOUGH TO BE A GOD!
Tread where MORTALS have not trod!
Be Deified, When Really, (You're a Sham! :O )
Be an Object of Devotion! o.o
Be the Subject of Psalms! O.o

It's a rather touching notion :3
All those prayers, and-those-salaams!!
And who am I to bridle if I'm *forced* to be an Idol?
IF THEY SAY THAT I'M A GOD, THAT'S WHAT I AM B\

So let's be Gods, the perks are great. El Dorado on our plates. Local feelings should not be rebuffed.

XENAGOS: Never rebuff, never rebuff a local feeling, no my friend.

Both: It's tough to be a God, but if you get the people's nod, count you blessings keep 'em sweet, thats our advice.

KIORA: It's great advice!

XENAGOS: Be a symbol of perfection, be a legend, be a cult.Take their praise, take a collection as the multitudes exalt.

Both: Don a supernatural habit, we'd be crazy not to grab it! So sign up two new Gods for paradise... par-a-dise!

378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.author: smarterman
378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.text_parsed: This guy is a monster in EDH especially as a commander. He instantly takes over the game and if you do not have a repeat way to keep him off the board he just takes over games winning them over and over and over again. Combined with Strionic Resonator it can turn a paltry 2/2 into a 8/8 every single turn for a mere two mana per turn. He turns Balefire Dragon into a one sided blasphemous act the turn it comes out. if your building an army he turns Wild Beastmaster with any counters into a instant game winner. I have played against six commander decks using him in MTGO so far and each time they won so quickly it seemed like the rest of the players didn't even get to play. Very very good for aggressive players.

378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.text_parsed: I've learned that Xenagod is an absolutely brutal commander. Having all your creatures come in able to attack with double their power is nuts, and you can even just slap some haste onto creatures with tap abilities if needed. Some of my favorites to use his ability on are Heroes' Bane (double his power twice!), Molimo (trample is awesome!), Terastodon (will no longer be killed by the three elephants you gave your opponent!) and of course alternate commanders Ruric Thar and Borborygmos.

378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.author: Phyrexian_Niv_Mizzet
378528: Xenagos, God of Revels.text_parsed:
My favorite BotG God, both flavor and mechanic wise. They killed this guy off way too soon, he could have made a great future antagonist. We don't get a lot of gruul aligned villains.

Card wise, he's a powerhouse in EDH. Tough to get rid of, amazing damage ramp and haste makes Xenagos a superb commander choice or include in any creature heavy deck. I wish he had only cost four, but in these colors it shouldn't be difficult to cast him by turn four or earlier anyway. 4/5.

Also, I kinda hope from a storyline perspective that a piece of him makes it to the underworld, just so that when Elspeth gets there, he's like, "So how'd working with Heliod work out for you?"

Can you trinket mage gilded lotus? proliforate shananigans, charge counter shananigens. If, like said, "in a vaccum", then I too would play lotus over this. But this isnt a vaccum, this magic. I for one will be excited to try this in my EDH decks.

378529: Astral Cornucopia.author: Eternal_Blue
378529: Astral Cornucopia.text_parsed:
You can pay any amount for X but it must be multiplied three times.

Here's a handy-dandy chart:

If you choose 0 mana, you pay 0+0+0, put zero counters on the Cornucopia, and tap it for zero mana.

If you choose 1 mana, you pay 1+1+1, put one counter on the Cornucopia, and tap it for one mana.

If you choose 2 mana, you pay 2+2+2, put two counters on the Cornucopia, and tap it for two mana.

If you choose 3 mana, you pay 3+3+3, put three counters on the Cornucopia, and tap it for three mana.

So if you have a lot of mana, you can have even more just by pouring massive amounts of mana into it. However, generally-speaking Gilded Lotus will probably be more than enough since it costs 5 mana for the Lotus and 9 mana to get the same effect with the Cornucopia.

378529: Astral Cornucopia.author: cardraptor6
378529: Astral Cornucopia.text_parsed:
Honestly, as a semi-broke EDH player I love it. I'm constantly using not just things like Chromatic Lantern and Darksteel Ignot but "sub-optimal" things like Manalith in my EDH decks as well, because I can't afford all the dumb broke mana-rocks from Magic's history. In most cases, this is another Manalith. In late game, it's a super-sized Manalith. Sure it's not indestructible, and there are some cases where the charge counters will hurt it, but fans of Everflowing Chalice will tell you that the situations where have charge counters are beneficial far outnumber the situations where it's detrimental.

Really glad I just pulled this in a prize pack prerelease, is what I'm trying to say.

378530: Gorgon's Head.author: Ferlord
378530: Gorgon's Head.text_parsed:
This card is getting bad rep because it's 'strictly worse' than Basilisk Collar and slightly less meaty than Gorgon Flail.

But this is one of the most punishing types of equipment limited can get: any colour can use it, adds immediate presence, isn't too expensive, and can turn a mediocre creature into a frightening blocker. Imagine you have an Archetype of Courage out. Who's going to attack you?

This shouldn't receive the 2.0 rating that it has now.

People, you have your legendary deck, make it happen.

378531: Heroes' Podium.author: nemokara
378531: Heroes' Podium.text_parsed:
Ugh. I want to like this card, but I just can't. Yeah, the flavor is tasty. But I feel like most of that could have been conserved while making this a more playable card outside of legend-themed EDH decks. Like maybe eliminating the word "other", making this at least a colorless legend-only anthem when you have only one legend, and probably averaging around +2/+2 or +3/+3 in ideal circumstances in the right deck. Or maybe an effect more like Door of Destinies? It would still represent a sort of legendary council, only each creature leaves behind some helpful knowledge/gear/inspirational writing/whatever when they leave. Or like fogguy suggested, remove the word "random" to give you the ability to order your cards à la Jar of Eyeballs. I dunno, maybe I'm underestimating the power of the pseudo-tutor effect.

I think my main grievance is it's just way too niche. Anyone who gets this in Draft or Sealed will feel bad, and it won't even get touched in Standard or other non-Commander constructed formats. This would be bad but not a huge problem if casual players and aspiring Johnnies could also use it. But the fact is that many kitchen table players won't own enough legends to make this useful as a build-around card. According to my quick search, in the sets since Shards of Alara, there's about a 3% chance for rares and 25% chance for mythics of getting a legendary creature (although there has been a lot of variance from those averages from set to set). Not very good odds for any relatively new casual player who only gets one or two dozen packs a set and doesn't trade or buy singles. For a player like that, this is probably worse than Search the City. Which is saying something.

This would be bad but not a huge problem if casual players and aspiring Johnnies could also use it. But the fact is that many kitchen table players won't own enough legends to make this useful as a build-around card. According to my quick search, in the sets since Shards of Alara, there's about a 3% chance for rares and 25% chance for mythics of getting a legendary creature (although there has been a lot of variance from those averages from set to set). Not very good odds for any relatively new casual player who only gets one or two dozen packs a set and doesn't trade or buy singles. For a player like that, this is probably worse than [autocard]Search the City[/autocard]. Which is saying something.

378533: Siren Song Lyre.author: Nucleon
378533: Siren Song Lyre.text_parsed:
Of note, you can pay the equip cost again to re-use the effect on another creature, not a bad late-game stallbreaker and mana sink in Limited at all. Sure, it costs 2 mana to cast, 2 to equip, and 2 use the effect, so that's an even-in-limited problem of 6 mana. But once it's equipped to something, as 4 mana can easily slip by in a stalemated turn, you get the much more useful dynamic of:

2T: Tap target creature.
4T: Tap two target creatures. (Repeat as mana and dorks permit).

Plus, as has been mentioned, a very handy inspired enabler, though not as good as Springleaf Drum for that particular use unless you start using it to tap multiple of your own creatures.

I'd honestly take this 4-5th pick of pack 1 in draft, especially if I didn't know what my signals and strategy were yet. It's pretty much a swiss army knife at uncommon that can be added to any Limited deck and have an acceptable use, or at least be sideboarded in.

4/5 stars for basic, simple utility that is handy to have pretty much anywhere, is at the best rarity for it, and doesn't feel under or overpowered.

378537: Temple of Plenty.author: Dabok
378537: Temple of Plenty.text_parsed:
@lorendorky : Yeah, I've also thought about the word fertility. Not only does it portray green/white very well in general, but especially on Theros with the G/W Karametra, God of Harvests, it shows the "agricultural" side of G/W.
Not that I'm complaining, the word "plenty" is reminiscent of Naya from Alara block, in that it's not about agriculture, it's the fact that nature offers ressources abundantly to all.

temple of malady B/G
temple of mystery U/G
temple of deceit B/U
temple of plenty W/G
temple of triumph W/R
temple of malice R/B
temple of enlightenment W/U
temple of epiphany R/U
temple of silence W/B
temple of abandon R/G
